Description: Ionian terracotta figure vase (plastic vase). Partially reconstructed from four joined fragments of upper body of aryballos in form of head of Achelous as bull. Mould-made, with 'black glaze' slip and applied white and red paint. Horns, eyes and ears were black, the beard is indicated by black stripes, and the forehead was outlined with alternate red and white dots, as was the upper part of the eye. The vase mouth rim was decorated on top with a cross. Fine pale cream Ionian clay fabric with sparse fine black inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Temple of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ5
Curator's comments: Marked Φ5 in pencil, from the final phase of the first temple of Aphrodite (re-built in c.525BC). Closest parallel for this fragmentary vessel is a mid 6th century BC example from Kamiros BM 1861,1024.5, originally thought to be of Rhodian origin, like this example (Higgins 1954: 46; 1959: 30-31). Higgins suggests this is from the same workshop BM 1861,1024.5. Same fabric as BM1888,0601.752a, BM1888,0601.752b and BM1888,0601.752c also from Naukratis. Jones' NAA analysis of BM1888,0601.752b places it within his Ionian B group (Jones 1986: 670). Jones, R.E., Greek and Cypriot pottery: a review of scientific studies, Athens, 1986; p.668-70
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (1628)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.028) (Phase 3)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Egypt Exploration Fund (Committee of)
